Fields.DialogueText: Buongiorno, Capitano.
Espero, what are you doing on...
Are you about to tell me there's a place on this ship I am not allowed?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not. That would be... ridiculous.
Would you obey if I did?
Everyone has a place on this ship. You need to learn yours.

Fields.DialogueText: Ridiculous, you say?
That would depend greatly on the circumstances.
Do I, now?
Capitano, you have much to learn.
You naturally know things, don't you?
Sì, many things. One of them I want to discuss with you. Unfortunately, I also know about the Morganas approaching from the north, so it may have to wait.
I guess I have to trust your word on that. All hands!
@BATTLE
All right, Espero. What is it you wanted to discuss?
Forgot about me, did you, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: I'm pretty busy, if you hadn't noticed.
I didn't know it was so easy to hurt your feelings.
How could I forget a personality like yours?

Fields.DialogueText: You think me so unobservant?
Let me assure you - my skin is thicker than yours.
Bene! That I'm pleased to hear.
But I digress. I'm here, speaking to you because I don't forget my friends. Napoli, in this instance.
The city?
The ship. A Regina Elena-class battleship built by Italy in 1908, to be precise. She was broken up for scrap in 1926, povera ragazza.
What interest do you have in ship scraps?
You aren't very good at listening to the whole story, are you? Her parts were shipped down to Massawa. The Eritreans have been rebuilding her to fight the Morganas.
...There's a story here.
And I want her.
For you or for her?
Oh, Capitano. I have the chance to help a friend and steal something from the Morganas at the same time. I'm going to take it.
You know that means we have to fight our way to the Red Sea.
Let me finish this cigarette, and I'll load the guns.
Sì.
As you know, the global nature of the Morgana threat has encouraged some of the great powers to expand and diversify their shipbuilding operations - as inexpensively as possible, of course.
So. A group of industrialists are conducting a kind of pilot program with engineers and shipwrights in Assab and Massawa - and I gather the early results have been quite positive.
Hm. I read early reports, but I hadn't realized things were already so far along.
It seems they are.
So, okay, they're trying to restore Napoli. And...?
The Morganas won't stop! Keep at it!
@BATTLE
So, we've made it to the Medi...
Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: This is insane. The Mediterranean is a shark pool.
Seems like everyone's fighting here.
I love a sea where I can shoot in any direction and hit a Morgana!

Fields.DialogueText: What, you don't feel like a swim, Capitano?
It's about time we join said fight.
How spirited of you, Capitano.
There are enough Italian bones on the bottom of this sea for it to be our mausoleum.
You can feel that history?
It is not easy to explain, Capitano. But yes.
Captain, I'm getting distress calls from French ships off the Tunisian coast!
Espero, how do you feel about taking Carthage again?
Hannibal had more honor than these creatures, I assure you. Let's put them down.
@BATTLE
How long have we been defending these French ships...
Wait, where's my pocket watch?
Questo? You mean this?

Fields.MenuText: You stole my pocket watch?!
I won't tolerate thievery on my ship, Espero.
Do you just take whatever you want?

Fields.DialogueText: It was just there for the taking, Capitano.
Then I suggest you find a different ship.
Parlando in generale? Yes.
How are we supposed to trust each other if you take my things?
Here. As a demonstration of my trust, I give you my new pocket watch. I was bored with it, anyway. It's only silver-plated.
Incorrigible.
The Morganas are coming back for another shot, Captain!
Would you like to try stealing from our enemies instead, Espero?
Let's see if they have anything worth pinching.
@BATTLE
We are approaching Tripoli, one of the newer gems in the Italian crown.
You can feel Italian holdings as well?
How do you think I know what's happening in Eritrea?

Fields.MenuText: I figured you had some bond with Napoli.
How am I supposed to understand you Belles?
I'm still not sure you do.

Fields.DialogueText: That much is true.
By taking the necessary time and consideration.
I suppose time will prove my ability.
... Dannazione.
What is it?
Morganas. They have mined the bay.
They have? Well, we can just go around.
No, Capitano. Italian ships could return here and sink in their own sanctuary. Are you ready to take down the Morgana defenses?
Oh, I am. But if Napoli, or what's left of her, is in urgent danger, it might be worth getting on the radio and making other arrangements.
Bene. Put out the call.
@BATTLE
No. We still have time.
... I'll take you at your word.
I feel a strange need to be here.
In Tobruk?
Yes ... it's odd, like a dream I can't picture. I need to defend this place.

Fields.MenuText: Makes sense. It's an Italian port.
Makes sense. It's strategically significant.
You don't make any sense to me.

Fields.DialogueText: That much is true.
I suppose that's correct.
The feeling is mutual.
Eppure ... I'm not sure. This protectiveness seems out of place.
Enemy fleet holding to the south, Captain!
It looks like I have the chance to help you with that, Espero.
You... would free Tobruk for me?
Yeah, but then you owe me one of those glasses of wine.
I have a Shiraz for just such a battle.
@BATTLE
Let's get to it. Avanti!
@BATTLE
Espero, I've been wondering about this ship we're going after.
What about it, Tesoro?
Was Napoli another Belle?
That's not her name anymore. She just has Italian pieces now.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, good. I couldn't handle another one like you.
The espresso and gelato pieces, I hope.
So she's an African Belle?

Fields.DialogueText: As if I would let you handle me.
Was that an attempt at humor?
Now you're on the right track.
She has some Italian identification, certainly, but she is distinctly African. Much like the Eritreans themselves.
So you can communicate with her?
I am... aware of her. And she is weak, incomplete. The local people are rushing to get her ready. They know the Morganas are closing in, and she is their flimsy hope of defense.
She's like a sister to you?
In un certo senso. She isn't a member of my Turbine-class, but we looked out for one another like sisters, nonetheless.
What are the chances that we can make it past Egypt without a fight?
Molto spiacevole. Non-existent.
Already?
*ALARM*
Wonderful.
@BATTLE
Molto bene, Tesoro. You know, we're passing Alexandria to the south. The Library at Alexandria. Now that would be a worthy heist.
I guess you'll have to settle for a sailor's lighter instead.
Been there, stolen that.
Give it back.
The Suez Canal is a great prize for any power.
The latest reports are that the Morganas hold it for now.
It's something I want and do not have. That, Tesoro, must be rectified.

Fields.MenuText: You have expensive taste.
What a woman wants, she gets.
Fighting in the canal is crazy.

Fields.DialogueText: Si. You're not wrong.
It would be good of you to remember that, Capitano.
Do you think yourself unequal to the task?
Captain! Morgana river vessels swarming out of the Nile Delta!
And I just lit this cigarette...
@BATTLE
We are coming near the Suez Canal. Be wary, Tesoro.
Whatever is waiting for us there, it can't be pretty.
Fortunatamente, I'm here to balance that out.

Fields.MenuText: You are endlessly confident, aren't you?
You said it, not me.
You certainly are a pleasant change of scenery.

Fields.DialogueText: I know what I'm capable of, Capitano. In situations like these, I can't help but be confident.
I see no need for false pretenses.
You flatter me, Capitano.
Now, I have some itchy guns for that blockade ahead.
You heard the lady, sailors! Let's scratch them off!
@BATTLE
The blockade is broken up. Shall we enter the Suez Canal?
Ladies first.
Oh, look at you learning, Tesoro.
Are those... Morganas lying in wait on the sides of the canal?!
Looks as if they're getting crafty.

Fields.MenuText: We're caught like fish in a barrel here!
Do you think we can make it out with a whole ship?
I'll take right if you take left.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we best bite before they have the chance to shoot.
I'm reasonably assured.
Bene. I'm already taking aim.
Whenever you're ready, then.
@BATTLE
We should have more room to maneuver here in the Gulf of Suez.
Captain, the Morganas are following at a distance!
They're likely waiting for us to come upon more of their friends to launch a full assault.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps we should turn about and take care of them, then.
There is just a handful of them. I'm not worried.
We could stop and let them catch up and play.

Fields.DialogueText: No, we can't waste any time getting to Massawa. Fire back at them while we continue forward.
I'm glad to hear you say as much, Capitano. We can fire back at them as we make our way to Massawa.
I suggest we keep moving and fire back at them.
A little target practice never hurt anyone. Except Morganas.
@BATTLE
Oh, here are the Morgana reinforcements. They appear to be transporting materials.
Looks like they want to take your canal, Espero.
The only thing the Morganas may steal from me is a spot on the bottom of the sea. Guns at your signal, Tesoro.
@BATTLE
Whew! The canal remains clear. That deserves a celebration.
Sì, davvero. Sangiovese or vernaccia?
Well, would you look at that?
The Red Sea. Finally.

Fields.MenuText: It's oddly... blue.
That was a lot of fighting for a narrow strip of water.
About time. I was getting claustrophobic.

Fields.DialogueText: What did you expect?
Many naval battles have been fought for less.
Were you, now?
Sometimes you reach into a purse and only find a comb. Sometimes you find a pouch of diamonds.
And what did I pull with you?
If you see this through, you will not be disappointed, Tesoro. Lo garantisco.
Morgana freighters pouring out of the Gulf of Aqaba, Captain!
Oh, of course. That would have been too easy.
@BATTLE
You know, Espero, I still don't know Napoli's new name.
Tetesfewe. It means 'to hope' in Tigrinya.
Of course. But the Eritreans *are* building her to fight the Morganas?
Sì. Currently, their only defense is the Red Sea Flotilla, which is ill-equipped to fight the British, much less the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Don't you feel bad stealing the Eritreans' only ship?
Will Tetesfewe even want to leave Eritrea?
Doesn't sound like they have a chance even with her.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm hard-pressed to remember a time I felt bad for stealing anything, ever.
I know her, Capitano.
Their chances are small.
Both Tetesfewe and the Eritreans just want to protect their people. If we can secure the Red Sea, we complete their objective for them. Everyone wins when we shoot Morganas.
Aw, Espero. You're just a big softy.
Don't make me turn the guns on the bridge, Tesoro.
Morganas coming in from the Arab side, Captain!
Looks like you won't have to, Espero.
Lucky you.
@BATTLE
Wait. Really? The Fascists are allowing something so... non-Italian?
The Regia Marina may not be fully aware of Tetesfewe's builders' plans. I believe they mean to offer service directly to the INPF in the hope they'll be able to secure some real autonomy.
And you're okay with that.
If I'm willing to work with the Soviets, I'm certainly willing to work with my sister - whoever she may be in her next life.
And, of course, we're going there to steal her anyway.
Do you ever get tired of the fighting, Espero?
As far as I am concerned, there are only two reasons to fight - when you are caught stealing and when a friend is in danger.
So this quest we're on...
Assolutamente giustificato. Unavoidable, even. Don't you agree?

Fields.MenuText: I think we could be doing a lot more good in the theaters that matter.
That's yet to be determined.
If we're not fighting for friends, what's the point?

Fields.DialogueText: The more friends we have, the bigger difference we can make in said theaters.
You think?
That's the sort of outlook I was hoping you'd have, Capitano.
Rest assured, Tetesfewe and I will both be indebted to you for this gesture.
Morgana vessels incoming from Jeddah, Captain!
I suppose this falls under 'caught stealing,' huh?
Sì, let's teach them to look the other way.
@BATTLE
I've noticed you've been getting a lot of attention from the crew, Espero.
Sì, it is to be expected.
And they're not the only ones, I've noted.

Fields.MenuText: Me? Surely you're mistaken.
What else do I have to look at?
I'll be the first to admit you're attractive.

Fields.DialogueText: Surely, I'm not.
It is true, this ship is lacking much in the way of beauty.
How kind of you, Capitano.
Just remember, no matter how much attention the crew pays me, you have no need to feel jealous.
I'm not...
Morganas coming right at us, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'm not jealous, you know.
So I stare. It doesn't mean anything.
Is there a particular reason I shouldn't be jealous?

Fields.DialogueText: You could use some practice complimenting a woman, Tesoro.
You could use some practice complimenting a woman, Tesoro.
You could use some practice complimenting a woman, Tesoro.
We are approaching Port Sudan, a strategic point in the Red Sea.
Which means...
It means we should probably prime the guns.
Look at that... Morganas are here all right, but the town is fighting back with artillery!
They will certainly lose without our involvement.
Sounds like a good reason to get scrappy.
Per la libertà e bottino.
@BATTLE
The people of Port Sudan are rebuilding their defenses. How do you feel about waiting here to defend them for a bit?
Asking my opinion now? My, my, Tesoro.
What?
What a leash I have on you.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have a leash on me, trust me.
I was just being considerate.
What can I say? I like a woman who orders me around.

Fields.DialogueText: You sound so assured of that fact, Capitano...
Was that what that was?
Is that a fact? How interesting, Tesoro...
I say we stay and defend them for a day.
Here they come!
Hold this town, people!
@BATTLE
What is that?
A scroll. It appears to date back to the 11th century.
Did you steal that from Port Sudan?
Tesoro, I wasn't going to travel all the way here and not steal something. Don't be foolish.
... Never mind. I'm happier not knowing.
It's a hobby. Shooting Morganas is just a dirty necessity. Speaking of which...
Maybe they want your scroll.
I will give them 120-millimeter shells. Questa è la mia offerta finale.
@BATTLE
How did you... I mean, you can barely leave the ship!
Do you steal something everywhere you go?
Bene. Let's get to it.
@BATTLE
We're entering Eritrean waters now. So far from the front of this war...
This is a global war now, Tesoro. Everywhere is the front.
I don't even know how you feel about the real war. I mean, the human war.
I am interested in the preservation of Italians and their heritage. And, of course, the unique prizes to be found in wartime.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you were getting sentimental there, at first.
Do you think Mussolini's interested in Italian preservation?
So... museums. You're interested in museums.

Fields.DialogueText: Sentiment is rare on my behalf.
I tend not to give much thought to Mussolini, in general.
I suppose that's one interpretation.
All loot aside, I do not think this war is beneficial to the Italian people. The war on the Morganas is. Thus, I tend to shoot Morganas.
I've noticed that. I'm glad you're on our side, Belle.
Oh, you're getting better at the compliments, Tesoro.
What?
Belle does also mean "beautiful."
I suppose that's true.
What are you drinking now?
Vernaccia. It's a white wine from San Gimignano—very crisp with good acidity and citrus tastes. It's too hot here for a red wine.
Seriously, the water is looking really good right ... what is that?!
Eritrean fishermen. They're being chased by the Morganas!
I've never seen someone paddle that hard. They don't stand a chance.
They do now, don't they, Tesoro?
Guns on those pursuing ships! Save the locals!
@BATTLE
We're getting close to Massawa.
Indeed.
Any idea what we'll find when we get there?
A fight for a whole country, I estimate.

Fields.MenuText: And it's not even our fight.
I hope it's worth risking my ships.
Then we'll have to make it count.

Fields.DialogueText: Any fight with the Morganas is our fight, Capitano.
No need to be so cynical before the battle has even started.
Vero. Your words are well chosen.
You're doing a good thing, Tesoro. And who knows the treasure you might steal!
That's really more your style.
Captain! We're overtaking some Morgana ships! Looks like they're heading to Massawa too!
This is one of the cardinal rules of thievery. Take your prize when the target is distracted.
Yeah, let's make this a little easier on ourselves. Guns at my signal!
@BATTLE
Dio mio, there it is...
Massawa is under siege! The Morganas want it bad!
There is the Red Sea Flotilla trying to fight them off. Hold on, amici...
They're completely surrounded. We'll have to punch our way through.
You'll have to bring all your guns to bear, Tesoro.

Fields.MenuText: For death and glory!
For Massawa!
This is such a bad idea!

Fields.DialogueText: Fortitudo Eius Rhodum Tenuit.
@BATTLE
Bene. Molto bene. We've made it through!
Finally...
Now we can begin pushing these mostri back.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, except now we're trapped between Massawa and Morganas!
We might have a chance if we can focus on the Red Sea Flotilla's targets.
My plan is just to shoot everything at this point.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll find a way out of this, somehow.
That's not a bad idea.
Perhaps a little more focus would be useful.
There, Tesoro! It's Tetesfewe! The Eritreans are bringing her out!
I hope they've equipped the old girl with some big guns!
She will fight for her motherland. We should protect her port side while she assists the flotilla to the south!
Okay, but there are plenty of Morganas coming after us! Looks like they want to take me as their prize now!
Tesoro, you are my prize, not theirs. I shall let them know.
That Espero...

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to have her as a partner in crime.
I'd like her as my partner... in more ways than one.
